dimensions.label: Relationship
dimensions.summary: How two or more variables move together.
dimensions.definition: Investigates associations or dependencies between variables (e.g. correlation, non-linear links, interactions).
nhs_examples: Emergency admissions vs GP appointment availability by PCN
Length of stay vs age for hip fracture patients
A&E 4-hour performance vs bed occupancy by site
common_questions: Do changes in X associate with changes in Y?
Is the relationship linear, curved, or segmented?
Does the association persist after case-mix adjustment?
pitfalls: Correlation ≠ causation; confounding is common in observational NHS data.
Spurious links from shared seasonality or common drivers.
Overplotting hides structure; consider transparency/binning/marginals.

dimensions.label: Composition
dimensions.summary: How a whole is split into parts and how parts change.
dimensions.definition: Part-to-whole relationships at a point in time or across time (static or stacked/compositional series).
nhs_examples: Elective vs non-elective admissions by month
Trust expenditure by category (pay, drugs, estates)
Primary vs community vs acute contacts for a cohort
common_questions: What share does each component contribute?
How do component shares change over time?
Are any small components driving overall changes?
pitfalls: Too many slices; prefer bars/treemap over many-segment donuts.
100% stacks obscure absolute changes; show totals or twin views.
Inconsistent denominators across units mislead part-to-whole.

dimensions.label: Distribution
dimensions.summary: Shape, spread, and outliers across people, places, or time.
dimensions.definition: How values are distributed for a metric: central tendency, variability, tails, and outliers; within or between groups.
nhs_examples: Waiting time distribution for RTT pathways
ED length-of-stay distribution by arrival mode
HbA1c results distribution across practices
common_questions: Is the distribution symmetric or skewed?
Are there extreme outliers or long tails?
Do group distributions differ meaningfully?
pitfalls: Overplotting in dense dots; aggregate to histograms or box/violin.
Comparing many groups with single histograms; use small multiples.
Ignoring sample size and data quality variation across providers.

dimensions.label: Comparison
dimensions.summary: Compare magnitudes across categories or over time.
dimensions.definition: Side-by-side assessment of values between groups, periods, or scenarios to establish differences in level.
nhs_examples: A&E breach rates by trust
Outpatient DNA rates by specialty
Bed occupancy by day of week
common_questions: Which units are above/below the average?
How large are the differences between groups?
How does the latest period compare to baseline?
pitfalls: Truncated axes exaggerate differences; use zero baseline where appropriate.
Sorting and labelling issues hinder quick ranking.
Mixing relative and absolute scales in one view confuses interpretation.

dimensions.label: Deviation
dimensions.summary: Difference from a target, baseline, or comparator.
dimensions.definition: Highlights positive/negative differences relative to plan, standard, or an expected value.
nhs_examples: Current performance vs NHS standard (e.g. 62-day cancer)
Variance to activity plan by month
SMR vs 100 benchmark across providers
common_questions: How far from target are we, and in which direction?
Is the deviation persistent or episodic?
Which components drive the deviation?
pitfalls: Mixing absolute and percentage deviation without clarity.
Ignoring uncertainty and expected common-cause variation.
Using colour scales that imply value judgements without context.

dimensions.label: Rank
dimensions.summary: Order units by a metric to show relative position.
dimensions.definition: Emphasises ordering and relative standing rather than exact values.
nhs_examples: Trusts ranked by A&E performance
PCNs ranked by QOF indicator achievement
ICBs ranked by vaccination coverage
common_questions: Who is best/worst performing?
How does rank change over time?
Are differences material or within noise?
pitfalls: Ranks exaggerate small differences when variance is low.
Alphabetical ordering misleads comparisons; always sort by value.
League tables without uncertainty can be misleading.

dimensions.label: Spatial
dimensions.definition: Looks at how values vary by place and spatial relationships between locations.
nhs_examples: Vaccination uptake by LSOA
ED attendance rates by trust catchment
Care home density vs admission rates
common_questions: Where are hotspots and coldspots?
Do nearby areas show similar values?
Is there spatial drift over time?
pitfalls: Choropleths mislead with unequal area sizes; consider cartograms.
Small populations create unstable rates; apply smoothing/aggregation.
Map projections and boundaries matter for interpretation.

dimensions.label: Change over time
dimensions.summary: Trend, seasonality, shifts, and cycles in time series.
dimensions.definition: A trend is a systematic movement in a time series beyond expected common-cause variation (e.g. monotonic trend, sustained shift, or repeating seasonal pattern). In NHS improvement work, SPC run rules help distinguish special-cause from common-cause variation.
nhs_examples: Waiting list size over months with a sustained upward trend
Seasonal ED attendances (winter peaks)
Step change after a service reconfiguration
common_questions: Is there a genuine trend or just random fluctuation?
Are there sustained shifts or runs indicating special-cause?
How does the latest value compare to the recent baseline?
pitfalls: Over-interpreting single-month spikes; assess against control limits.
Ignoring seasonality; include seasonal context or decomposition.
Comparing raw counts without population/activity adjustment.

components.label: People (patients, staff)
components.summary: Individuals or cohorts as units of analysis.
components.notes: Often analysed via distributions (e.g., LOS), counts, or rates over time.

components.label: Resources/Capacity
components.summary: Staff, beds, theatres, equipment and other capacity elements.
components.notes: Use matrix for schedules (e.g., hour × weekday utilisation); time series for capacity vs demand over time; categories for unit‑level comparison.

components.label: Events (attendances, harms)
components.notes: For rare harms consider G/T charts; for volume trends use run/SPC.

components.label: Organisations/Units
components.notes: Use bar/rank for categories; maps/funnels for spatial/volume-varying.

components.label: Geographic areas
components.notes: Prefer normalised rates on choropleths; consider cartograms.

components.label: Time periods
components.notes: Run/SPC for change; calendar heatmap for periodicity.

components.label: Categories/Reasons
components.notes: Pareto to prioritise; waterfall for positive/negative components.

components.label: Utilisation
components.summary: How resources are used relative to capacity over time and across schedules.
components.definition: Examines occupancy/load versus available capacity, often by time of day and day of week, to identify under/over‑utilisation and scheduling opportunities.
nhs_examples: Theatre utilisation by session and weekday
MRI scanner occupancy by hour of day
Clinic slot fill rates vs capacity
common_questions: When are resources under or over‑utilised?
How does utilisation vary by hour/day/ward?
Is demand aligned to capacity provisioning?
pitfalls: Ignoring no‑shows and overruns when judging utilisation.
Comparing raw counts without normalising by capacity.
Overusing gauges; prefer quantitative scales and trends.

components.label: Flow
components.summary: Movement of patients/items through stages or between places.
components.definition: Shows how entities progress across pathway stages or locations, highlighting accumulation, bottlenecks, and throughput.
nhs_examples: Referral → triage → outpatient → admission → discharge
A&E triage to treatment stages with handoffs
Discharge to community care pathways
common_questions: Where do bottlenecks occur in the process?
How many items are in each stage over time?
How do flows differ by site or specialty?
pitfalls: Sankey with too many nodes; aggregate stages.
Cumulative totals misread as instantaneous WIP.
Flow maps imply causality; show volumes clearly.

goals.label: Analyse trends
goals.summary: Detect and communicate change over time.
goals.definition: A trend is a systematic movement in a time series beyond expected common-cause variation. This includes monotonic trends, sustained shifts (e.g. series of points above/below the centre line), and seasonal patterns. SPC run rules (e.g. 6–8 points on one side, 5 increasing/decreasing, or points beyond control limits) help identify special-cause variation.
nhs_examples: Sustained increase in RTT backlog after a policy change
Seasonal peaks in respiratory admissions
Reduction in DNAs following reminder interventions
pitfalls: Reacting to common-cause variation as if it were special-cause.
Ignoring seasonality and service calendar effects (bank holidays).
Not annotating known interventions or data definition changes.

goals.label: Manage capacity & utilisation
goals.summary: Align demand with available capacity to improve utilisation.
goals.definition: Monitor and balance resource capacity against demand patterns by time and place, identifying under/over‑utilisation and scheduling opportunities.
nhs_examples: Theatre and clinic utilisation by session
Bed occupancy vs discharges by hour
Imaging capacity vs bookings
pitfalls: Using gauges without scale; prefer quantitative scales.
Not normalising by capacity when comparing utilisation.
Ignoring seasonality and appointment mix.

goals.label: Improve patient/service flow
goals.summary: Reveal bottlenecks and WIP across stages to improve throughput.
goals.definition: Visualise flows across pathway stages or locations and levels of work‑in‑progress over time to target improvement.
nhs_examples: ED triage → treatment → discharge bottlenecks
Elective referral to treatment flow
Discharge pathway handoffs
pitfalls: Too many nodes lead to visual clutter; group stages.
Confusing cumulative vs instantaneous measures.
Attributing causality without supporting evidence.

goals.label: Monitor operational status
goals.summary: Track backlogs, thresholds, and exceptions for action.
goals.definition: Operational monitoring dashboards highlight current status versus targets and identify exceptions that need action.
nhs_examples: Backlog trend with burn‑down target
Threshold breaches for key KPIs
Watchlist of services with special‑cause variation
pitfalls: Overuse of traffic lights without context.
Static thresholds on noisy processes; use SPC.
Dashboards without linked action owners.

goals.label: Understand relationships
goals.definition: Explore whether variables co-vary, accounting for possible confounding and non-linear patterns. Use stratification or faceting to uncover interactions.
nhs_examples: Bed occupancy vs A&E 4-hour breaches by site
Length of stay vs age or frailty score
Deprivation vs screening uptake across PCNs
pitfalls: Assuming causality from correlation.
Overplotting hides subgroups; facet or sample.
Confounding by seasonality or population mix.

goals.label: Demonstrate deviation
goals.summary: Show difference from target or baseline.
goals.definition: Quantify positive/negative variance to plan, standard, or expected value, and attribute where possible.
nhs_examples: Variance to elective activity plan by specialty
Performance vs constitutional standards
Mortality index vs national benchmark
pitfalls: Mixing absolute and percentage variance without clarity.
Cherry-picking baselines to overstate deviation.
Ignoring uncertainty/control limits when judging ‘off target’.

goals.label: Demonstrate magnitude
goals.summary: Emphasise sizes and differences in level.
goals.definition: Compare absolute or relative values to convey size of a measure across categories or periods.
nhs_examples: Outpatient activity volumes by specialty
ICS spend by programme
Bed days by ward
pitfalls: Truncated axes exaggerate small differences.
Overuse of 3D/area encodings harms readability.
Too many categories; group or filter for focus.

goals.label: Geographical patterns
goals.definition: Map and analyse geographic patterns, considering unequal area sizes and population denominators.
nhs_examples: Vaccination coverage by LSOA
Emergency admissions per 1,000 by ICS
Patient flows between trusts
pitfalls: Raw counts on maps mislead; normalise by population/activity.
Small-number instability; aggregate or smooth.
Colour scales that hide key thresholds.

goals.label: Show composition
goals.definition: Break down totals into meaningful components and track contributions over time.
nhs_examples: Drug spend by BNF chapter
Staff costs by staff group
Pathway contacts by setting
pitfalls: Too many segments; prioritise or group small parts.
100% stacks hide absolute change; show totals alongside.
Donuts with many slices reduce readability.

goals.label: Show rank
goals.definition: Present relative position clearly, with attention to practical significance and uncertainty.
nhs_examples: Trusts ranked by Friends and Family Test positivity
PCNs ranked by long-term condition prevalence
Wards ranked by patient flow metrics
pitfalls: Rank differences may be within noise; show values/intervals.
Long labels clutter; rotate or abbreviate with care.
Beware Simpson’s paradox when ranking aggregated data.

goals.label: Understand distribution
goals.definition: Characterise variation within and between groups to inform targeting and equity analyses.
nhs_examples: Distribution of waiting times by specialty
HbA1c result distribution across practices
Ward-level length of stay distribution
pitfalls: Overplotting and binning choices can mislead.
Comparing groups with very different sizes; normalise or weight.
Hiding tails through clipping or narrow axes.

nhs.notes: Encodes NHS visualisation goals and their decision hierarchy as a wizard.

chart_types_add.name: Utilisation heatmap
cautions: Avoid when exact values are needed; use labels or a table instead

chart_types_add.name: Sankey (alluvial)
cautions: Avoid too many nodes/links; diagrams become unreadable

chart_types_add.name: Cumulative flow diagram
cautions: Avoid very short time windows; accumulation needs stable categories

chart_types_add.name: Burn-down chart
cautions: Avoid accumulated totals; use cumulative flow for work-in-progress

chart_types_add.name: Progress bar
cautions: Avoid dense comparisons across many items; use a table or bars

chart_types_add.name: Card
good_for: Summarising a single metric or entity with context
Responsive dashboards with mixed metadata
cautions: Limited space for dense comparisons; defer to tables/charts
Ensure consistent layout for scannability across a set

chart_types_add.name: Card list
good_for: Mobile‑friendly alternative to wide tables
Showing richer metadata per item (owner, tags, actions)
Actionable worklists on mobile (triage/assign/fix)
cautions: Harder to compare values column‑wise than a table
May require explicit sort/filter controls for scanning

chart_types_add.name: Pivot table
good_for: Exploring large datasets across multiple categorical dimensions
Rapidly slicing metrics by rows/columns with subtotals
cautions: Complex for non‑expert audiences; provide presets and guidance
Totals and percentages can confuse without clear denominators

chart_types_add.name: Calendar
good_for: Appointments/rosters with day/week/month grids
Communicating service schedules alongside counts
cautions: Month grids bias weekday patterns; not ideal for rates
Use calendar_heatmap for dense aggregated values

chart_types_add.name: Table
good_for: Precise values and long labels
Mixed units and contextual notes
Accessible alternative or complement to charts
Triage workflows (duplicates, invalid codes, missing fields)
cautions: Patterns less evident than charts; add sorting or highlights
Ensure accessible markup and responsive behaviour

chart_types_add.name: KPI tile
good_for: Top-line KPIs in dashboards
Latest value with change vs baseline
cautions: Needs context; pair with sparkline or link to detail
Avoid traffic-light overuse without explanation

chart_types_add.name: SPC (control) chart
good_for: Detecting special-cause vs common-cause variation
Sustained shifts and trends around a process mean
cautions: Needs enough data (≈20–25 points) to stabilise limits
Not ideal for very short series; start with a run chart
Assumes roughly stable process and independent observations

chart_types_add.name: Run chart
good_for: Early detection of non-random patterns without control limits
Communicating median-centred runs tests
cautions: No control limits; do not interpret as SPC
Median choice matters; recompute after process change

chart_types_add.name: Funnel plot
good_for: Comparing providers with different volumes and uncertainty
Spotting outliers beyond control limits
cautions: Requires appropriate denominator and risk adjustment
Overdispersion may require Laney variants (p'/u')

chart_types_add.name: Pareto chart
good_for: Finding the vital few contributors
Prioritising improvement focus
cautions: Requires consistent categorisation; beware small counts variance

chart_types_add.name: CUSUM chart
good_for: Early detection of small sustained shifts
cautions: Choice of k/h parameters affects sensitivity and false alarms

chart_types_add.name: EWMA chart
good_for: Smoothed detection of gradual change
cautions: Lambda choice balances sensitivity vs noise

chart_types_add.name: G chart (days between)
good_for: Rare events measured as days between occurrences
cautions: Assumes independent rare events; annotate data quality changes

chart_types_add.name: T chart (time between)
good_for: Irregular continuous time between rare events
cautions: Requires reliable event timestamping

chart_types_add.name: Forest plot
good_for: Showing estimates with confidence intervals across units
cautions: Ensure consistent effect measures and scales

chart_types_add.name: SPC sparkline
good_for: Compact dashboard tiles showing SPC state
cautions: Compact format limits labels and annotation

chart_types_add.name: Seismogram
good_for: high-frequency continuous signal over time
cautions: Specialised; domain-specific interpretation

chart_types_add.name: Fan chart
cautions: Avoid implying precision with short histories; bands may be unreliable

chart_types_add.name: Priestley timeline
cautions: Avoid many overlapping intervals; prefer Gantt or small multiples

chart_types_add.name: Gantt chart
good_for: Showing task intervals and dependencies over calendar time
Service schedules and pathway step durations
cautions: Not suited to aggregated metrics; use timelines for many entities
Dense labels require grouping or zooming for readability

chart_types_add.name: Calendar heatmap
cautions: Avoid direct rate comparisons across months; month lengths vary

chart_types_add.name: Circle timeline
cautions: Avoid when precise length comparison matters; use a linear timeline

chart_types_add.name: Area chart
cautions: Avoid comparing many overlapping series; consider lines or stacked area

chart_types_add.name: Dual-axis chart
good_for: Capacity vs demand when metrics have different units (e.g., slots vs attendances)
Two series with distinct natural scales where normalisation isn't possible
cautions: Risk of misreading due to scale mismatch; use sparingly
Align or normalise scales; clearly label axes and units
Avoid implying correlation from co-trending due to shared time axis
Consider small multiples as a safer alternative

chart_types_add.name: Line and Column (combo)
cautions: Avoid mixing different units on one axis; normalise or split charts

chart_types_add.name: Diverging bar
cautions: Avoid many categories; labels and interpretation become crowded

chart_types_add.name: Surplus/Deficit filled line
cautions: Avoid when series rarely crosses baseline; a simple area may suffice

chart_types_add.name: Diverging stacked bar
cautions: Avoid many segments; hard to compare non-aligned stacks

chart_types_add.name: Spine chart
cautions: Avoid when values aren’t naturally opposing; a standard bar may be clearer

chart_types_add.name: Lollipop chart
cautions: Avoid when tiny differences must be read precisely; bars can be clearer

chart_types_add.name: Radar chart
cautions: Hard to compare angles/areas; consider parallel coordinates

chart_types_add.name: Isotype pictogram
cautions: Avoid precise comparisons; unit rounding can distort totals

chart_types_add.name: Parallel coordinates
cautions: Avoid too many dimensions or rows; overplotting requires interaction or sampling

chart_types_add.name: Paired bar chart
cautions: Avoid large category counts; pairing becomes cluttered

chart_types_add.name: Paired column chart
cautions: Avoid long labels and many pairs; readability suffers

chart_types_add.name: Dot density map
cautions: Avoid when precise counts or rates are needed; dot placement is illustrative

chart_types_add.name: Flow map
good_for: Showing movement between locations (origins and destinations)
Comparing volumes along routes or corridors
Highlighting dominant flows after aggregating small ones
cautions: Avoid dense overlaps; aggregate or filter flows for clarity

chart_types_add.name: Contour map
good_for: Visualising continuous fields as bands or lines
Showing equal-value contours (e.g., travel time isochrones)
cautions: Avoid sparse input points; interpolation can mislead

chart_types_add.name: Geospatial heat map
good_for: Revealing hotspots and concentration patterns
Exploring spatial intensity when exact counts aren't required
cautions: Avoid implying totals; density shows concentration, not counts

chart_types_add.name: Equalised cartogram
good_for: Comparing regions without area bias using equal-sized shapes
Displaying categorical status or rates with fair visual weighting
cautions: Avoid tasks needing geographic accuracy; shapes are distorted

chart_types_add.name: Proportional symbol map
good_for: Comparing magnitudes at specific locations
Overlaying counts or rates on a base map
cautions: Avoid severe overlap; use clustering or alternate map types

chart_types_add.name: Scaled cartogram
good_for: Emphasising totals by scaling region area to value
Communicating relative importance of regions despite geographic size differences
cautions: Avoid unfamiliar audiences; pair with a reference map

chart_types_add.name: Donut chart
cautions: Avoid many slices or close values; bars compare proportions more clearly

chart_types_add.name: Grid plot (waffle)
cautions: Avoid many categories or large totals; grids become unwieldy

chart_types_add.name: Sunburst
cautions: Avoid deep hierarchies; inner rings dominate perception

chart_types_add.name: Venn diagram
cautions: Avoid more than 3 sets; readability drops sharply

chart_types_add.name: Bullet graph
cautions: Avoid inconsistent scales across items; standardise axes

chart_types_add.name: Dot strip plot
cautions: Avoid very large n without jitter/transparency; overplotting hides density

chart_types_add.name: Population pyramid
cautions: Avoid unequal group sizes without normalising; consider rates per population

chart_types_add.name: Cumulative curve
cautions: Avoid non-specialist audiences without explanation; interpretation is less intuitive

chart_types_add.name: Barcode plot
cautions: Avoid high-density datasets without transparency; lines merge into blocks

chart_types_add.name: Ordered proportional symbol
cautions: Avoid overlapping symbols; ensure ordering and spacing aid comparison

chart_types_add.name: Kanban board
good_for: Triage/assignment workflows with status columns
Visual WIP limits and SLA ageing by lane
cautions: Avoid very large item counts; prefer list/table for bulk ops

chart_types_add.name: Master–detail view
good_for: Fast review and disposition with details panel
Approve/clear exceptions with context
cautions: Avoid overloading detail pane; keep actions focused

chart_types_add.name: Editable grid
good_for: Bulk validation and recoding with inline edits
Resolve missing/invalid values efficiently
cautions: Requires robust audit trail and validation rules

chart_types_add.name: Review workbench
good_for: Queue-based review and batch disposition
Approve, defer, reassign with keyboard speed
cautions: Train users on shortcuts; guard against mass errors

chart_types_add.name: Duplicate merge view
good_for: Comparing suspected duplicate pairs and merging with audit
Highlighting conflicting fields and suggested winners
cautions: Needs deterministic merge rules and rollback plan

chart_types_add.name: Scheduler board
good_for: Assigning clinics/lists to people/rooms with drag and drop
Resolving clashes and filling gaps quickly
cautions: Complex permissions; ensure audit and conflict rules

chart_types_add.name: Map + list
good_for: Acting on geographically distributed items (e.g., visits, homecare)
Selecting by map area and actioning in a list
cautions: Avoid map-only; ensure list parity for accessibility

chart_types_add.name: Segment builder
good_for: Composing filters and fields before export or operations
Saving reusable views for recurring tasks
cautions: Guardrail complexity; guide with templates

chart_types_add.name: Data uploader
good_for: Importing corrections or new records with inline validation
Previewing changes and applying in batches
cautions: Require rollbacks and audit for applied changes

components_root.question: What are your components (unit of analysis)?
components_root.help: Components are the 'things' or entities your data describes (e.g., patients, trusts, clinics, time periods). Choose all that apply.

choices.label: Services/Pathways
choices.help: e.g. RTT pathway, screening programme, specialty clinic.

choices.label: People
choices.help: e.g. patients, staff, carers.

choices.label: Organisations/Units
choices.help: e.g. trust, site, PCN, ward, team.

choices.label: Resources/Capacity
choices.help: e.g. staff, beds, theatres, equipment, slots.

choices.label: Events
choices.help: e.g. attendances, admissions, harms, breaches.

choices.label: Geographic Areas
choices.help: e.g. postcode, LSOA, ICS, region.

choices.label: Time Periods
choices.help: e.g. days, weeks, months, quarters.

choices.label: Categories/Reasons
choices.help: e.g. diagnosis, procedure, priority, reason code.

components_shape.question: Which best describes your data shape?
components_shape.help: Shape is the structure of your data, not the subject matter (e.g., matrix for utilisation schedules across hour × weekday; time series for capacity vs demand).

choices.label: Time series (observations over time)
choices.help: Values tracked over dates/periods. e.g. daily attendances, weekly referrals, monthly bed days.

choices.label: Categories (groups like trusts/specialties)
choices.help: One value per category. e.g. occupancy by ward, throughput by clinic, metrics by specialty.

choices.label: Hierarchy (nested categories)
choices.help: Parent → child groupings. e.g. org → site → ward; programme → workstream → project.

choices.label: Matrix (multiple variables per item)
choices.help: Grid/cross‑tab. e.g. utilisation by hour × weekday, measure × stage, unit × metric.

choices.label: Spatial (areas/points on a map)
choices.help: Geographic data. e.g. rates by postcode/LSOA, locations on a map, trust boundaries.

components_measure.question: What kind of measure are you showing?
components_measure.help: Pick the type that matches how your metric is recorded.

choices.label: Count (events per period)
choices.help: Whole-number totals in a time window. e.g. ED attendances/day, falls/month, clinics/week.

choices.label: Rate/Proportion/Percentage
choices.help: A count relative to a denominator (or total). e.g. % DNA, admissions per 1,000 pop, A&E 4‑hour %.

choices.label: Continuous value (time, length of stay, lab value)
choices.help: Measured on a continuous scale. e.g. LOS (days), HbA1c mmol/mol, turnaround time (minutes).

choices.label: Categorical outcome (yes/no) by group
choices.help: Binary outcomes summarised by unit. e.g. compliance yes/no, target met/not, adverse event occurred.

components_rate.question: Are you comparing providers/units with varying denominators?
components_rate.help: Whether units have different opportunity sizes (denominators), e.g., admissions per 1,000 population or % DNA by clinic list size; this affects fair comparison.

yes.help: Yes if denominators differ; funnel plots adjust for opportunity size to avoid unfair comparisons.

no.help: No if denominators are similar or not used; standard comparisons apply.

components_count.question: Is it a rare-event metric (many zeros)?
components_count.help: Whether events are infrequent with many zeros per period (rare events).

yes.help: Yes for rare events with many zeros; time‑between (G/T) charts can read clearer than counts.

no.help: No if counts per period are common; standard time‑series charts apply.

components_continuous.question: Prefer smoothed detection of gradual change?
components_continuous.help: Whether you prefer a smoothed signal to detect gradual change (e.g., using EWMA).

yes.help: Yes to smooth noise and reveal subtle shifts; EWMA helps detect gradual change.

no.help: No if you prefer raw unsmoothed values; use standard time‑series or SPC if needed.

components_binary.question: Do you want to show estimates with confidence intervals by unit?
components_binary.help: Whether to show unit‑level estimates with confidence intervals to reflect uncertainty.

yes.help: Yes to show unit estimates with confidence intervals; a forest plot presents this clearly.

no.help: No if you don’t need confidence intervals; simple proportions or tables may suffice.

components_cardinality.question: How many components are you comparing at once?

choices.label: One
choices.help: Single component or unit.

choices.label: Two
choices.help: Compare two components side‑by‑side.

choices.label: A few (3–10)
choices.help: Small set; overlays or small multiples can work.

choices.label: Many (10+)
choices.help: Larger set; small multiples, summaries, or tables often clearer.

presentation_pref.question: What is your preferred presentation?
presentation_pref.help: Consider audience, device, and task — do you need to scan, compare, or act? Analysts may need exact values; operational users often prefer concise summaries and status at a glance or quick call's to prioritised actions. Don't assume that a large dataset must be shown all at once.

choices.label: Precise values / long labels
choices.help: For analysts and audits. Exact numbers, long text, and mixed units. Best for exporting, where possible/drilling down into operational detail.

choices.label: Summary overview / ops-dashboard or mobile‑friendly
choices.help: For quick scanning on phones or operational dashboards. Show key fields and a small trend; defer dense comparisons.

choices.label: Dashboard tile (headline and trend)
choices.help: For status at a glance. Latest value, change vs baseline, and compact sparkline. Link to detail for context.

choices.label: Actionable list (triage/fix)
choices.help: For taking action now. List items needing attention with inline actions (e.g., resolve duplicates, correct codes, reassign). Use sort/filter to prioritise.

choices.label: No preference
choices.help: Keep options open; we’ll balance clarity, precision, and space.

nhs_root.question: What do you want do you want to achieve by visualising this data, what do you want your users to do?
nhs_root.help: Choose the primary decision or action you want this visualisation to support. Pick the goal that best matches the user’s task; we’ll guide you to chart types that suit that purpose.

choices.label: Analyse trends
choices.help: Track change over time; spot shifts, trends, and seasonality.

choices.label: Manage capacity & utilisation
choices.help: Balance capacity and demand; view utilisation patterns and schedules.

choices.label: Improve patient/service flow
choices.help: Understand movement between stages and where bottlenecks occur.

choices.label: Monitor operational status
choices.help: Provide status at a glance: backlogs, targets/thresholds, exceptions.

choices.label: Operate on data (triage/fix)
choices.help: Take action directly on records: resolve duplicates, validate/recode values, assign/route to owners, or approve/clear exceptions.

choices.label: Better understand relationships
choices.help: Explore associations/correlation between variables; stratify or facet where needed.

choices.label: Demonstrate deviation
choices.help: Show variance from target/baseline or benchmark; highlight positive/negative differences.

choices.label: Demonstrate magnitude
choices.help: Compare sizes/levels across categories or periods.

choices.label: Visualise geographical patterns
choices.help: Reveal spatial variation and clusters across areas or locations.

choices.label: Show composition
choices.help: Explain part‑to‑whole structure and contributions over time.

choices.label: Show rank
choices.help: Highlight ordering and relative position across units.

choices.label: Understand the distribution
choices.help: See spread, skew, and outliers within and between groups.

ops_action_q0.question: What action do you want to take on the data?
ops_action_q0.help: Choose the primary operation to perform on records. We’ll suggest list-based views that support prioritisation, filtering, and inline actions.

choices.label: Resolve duplicates
choices.help: Identify/merge suspected duplicates. Suggested columns: duplicate key(s), pair id, confidence, owner, age/SLA, status. Common filters: confidence, owner/team, status, age.

choices.label: Validate & recode
choices.help: Fix missing/invalid values with audit notes. Suggested columns: field, current value, suggested/valid code, rule/reason, owner, last updated. Filters: issue type, field, owner, status.

choices.label: Assign/route to owner
choices.help: Prioritise and (re)assign items. Suggested columns: priority/severity, type, owner/team, age/SLA, queue/status. Filters: priority, owner/team, status, age.

choices.label: Approve / clear exceptions
choices.help: Disposition exceptions (approve, defer, clear) with comment. Columns: exception type, severity, reason, owner, age, status. Filters: type, severity, owner, status, age.

choices.label: Prepare / export dataset
choices.help: Choose fields/filters and export. Tips: save views, include date range, dedupe/flag data quality. Outputs: CSV/Parquet as needed.

op_cap_q0.question: Capacity/utilisation focus?
op_cap_q0.help: Use heatmaps for hour × weekday utilisation patterns. Use time‑series (line/area/combo/dual‑axis) for capacity vs demand trends. To spotlight free/unused capacity, plot available = capacity − used or 100% − utilisation; the chart type stays the same.

choices.label: Capacity vs demand over time
choices.help: Compare trends across periods; we’ll ask about small multiples and units/scales next. Add a 'remaining capacity' series to highlight gaps.

choices.label: Utilisation by hour/day
choices.help: Hour × weekday patterns to reveal peaks/troughs and quiet times. To spot gaps, show 'free capacity' (100% − utilisation) or use an inverse colour scale.

choices.label: Rosters & scheduling
choices.help: Show shifts, clinics, and lists over calendar time.

choices.label: Single KPI utilisation
choices.help: Status at a glance for one metric; pair with a small trend if needed.

op_cap_small_multiples.question: Would you prefer small multiples (one chart per unit) instead of overlaying series?
op_cap_small_multiples.help: Small multiples are a grid of like‑for‑like mini charts (one per unit) using the same scales. They help compare patterns across many units without overlapping lines.

yes.help: Yes to avoid overlays and dual‑axis pitfalls; best for many units side‑by‑side.

no.help: No to overlay series in a single chart; fine for a few units where lines remain readable.

op_cap_capacity_demand_units.question: Do capacity and demand use different units/scales (e.g., slots vs attendances)?
op_cap_capacity_demand_units.help: Whether capacity and demand are measured on different scales (e.g., slots vs attendances).

yes.help: Yes if units/scales differ; combo or careful dual‑axis can help — small multiples are often safer.

no.help: No if units/scales are the same; standard line/area/combo charts work well.

op_flow_q0.question: What flow do you want to show?
op_flow_q0.help: Choose a flow perspective: stage transitions (Sankey/CFD), movements between places (flow map), or durations/handoffs (Gantt).

choices.label: Across pathway stages
choices.help: Volumes moving between stages. e.g. referrals → triage → clinic → discharge.

choices.label: Between locations
choices.help: Origins/destinations. e.g. patient transfers or flow between sites/wards.

choices.label: Stage durations / handoffs
choices.help: How long each step takes and where waits occur.

op_status_q0.question: Operational status focus?
op_status_q0.help: Pick the status view you need: backlog trend, target progress at a glance, or an actionable exceptions list for attention.

choices.label: Backlog / queue length
choices.help: Track workload over time and its rate of change.

choices.label: Thresholds / targets
choices.help: Show progress vs a limit/target and current status at a glance.

choices.label: Exceptions watchlist
choices.help: List outliers, duplicates, or invalid codes needing attention now. Suggested columns: type, severity, owner, age/SLA. Common filters: type, severity, owner, status.

choices.label: Data quality issues
choices.help: Identify and act on data problems (duplicates, missing fields, invalid codes). Suggested columns: issue type, primary key(s), affected fields, last seen/updated, owner. Common filters: issue type, age, owner, status. Use sort/filter and inline actions to resolve items.

trend_q1.question: Is it predictive?
trend_q1.help: Whether you need to include forecasts/projections with uncertainty bands.

yes.help: Yes to include projections with uncertainty bands (forecasts).

no.help: No if you’re not forecasting; use observed data only.

trend_q2.question: Is duration important?
trend_q2.help: Whether intervals, overlaps, and durations matter more than point values.

yes.help: Yes when start–end intervals/overlaps are primary; timelines show durations clearly.

no.help: No if point values are primary; continue with standard time‑series.

trend_q3.question: Are you looking at temporal patterns (daily/weekly/monthly)?
trend_q3.help: Whether you want to highlight daily/weekly/monthly temporal patterns.

yes.help: Yes to highlight cyclical patterns; calendar heatmaps show them clearly.

no.help: No if cyclical daily/weekly/monthly patterns aren’t the focus.

trend_q3a.question: Is early detection of small sustained shifts important?
trend_q3a.help: Whether early detection of small sustained shifts is important.

yes.help: Yes for earlier detection of subtle change; CUSUM/EWMA highlight shifts sooner than run/SPC.

no.help: No if standard run/SPC change detection is sufficient.

trend_q3b.question: Is it a rare-event metric (days/time between harms)?
trend_q3b.help: Whether the measure is rare events where time between events is meaningful.

yes.help: Yes for rare‑event metrics; G/T charts can be clearer than period counts.

no.help: No if period counts are your primary measure.

trend_q4.question: Is there an additional dimension?
trend_q4.help: Whether you need to encode an additional dimension (e.g., magnitude or cycle phase).

yes.help: Yes to add an extra dimension; consider a radial timeline or area.

no.help: No if a standard timeline suffices without extra dimensions.

trend_q5.question: Are you comparing two variables?
trend_q5.help: Whether you’re comparing two variables over time.

yes.help: Yes for two-variable comparisons; connected scatter shows relationships; dual‑axis needs careful scales/units.

no.help: No if you’re focusing on a single variable over time.

trend_q6.question: Is detail unimportant?
trend_q6.help: Whether fine‑grained detail is unimportant and you only need start→end change.

yes.help: Yes when detail is unimportant and you just need start→end change; a slope chart is concise.

no.help: No when you need detailed values and shape over time; use standard time‑series.

rel_q0.question: What kind of data?
rel_q0.help: Choose whether your variables are numeric (interval) or ordered categories (ordinal). Interval supports magnitude and arithmetic; ordinal supports rank/ordering but not equal spacing.

choices.label: Interval (quantitative)
choices.help: Numeric measurements on a scale. e.g. rates, durations, counts.

choices.label: Ordinal (ordered categories)
choices.help: Categories with rank/ordering. e.g. low/medium/high, quintiles, ratings.

rel_interval_q1.question: How many variables?
rel_interval_q1.help: Pick the number of variables to compare. For two variables, decide if the split is over time or across categories; for three, encode the third as size/colour/shape.

choices.label: 2 (split by time)
choices.help: Two variables shown over time. e.g. capacity vs demand.

choices.label: 2 (split by other)
choices.help: Two variables compared across categories.
Add a third variable as size/colour/shape.

dev_q0.question: What deviation pattern?
dev_q0.help: Select how you want to show deviation: simple above/below a baseline, across two measures, contrasting components, volume‑adjusted provider comparison, or unit estimates with uncertainty.

choices.label: Positive/negative (1 dimension)
choices.help: Above vs below a baseline or expected value.

choices.label: Two dimensions
choices.help: Deviations along two measures (e.g. value and variance).

choices.label: Two contrasting components
choices.help: Opposing parts of the whole (e.g. surplus vs deficit).

choices.label: By provider vs benchmark (varying volumes)
choices.help: Compare performance adjusted for denominator size.

choices.label: Estimates with confidence intervals by unit
choices.help: Show point estimates with uncertainty for each unit.

dev_q1.question: Static or over time?
dev_q1.help: Choose a one‑off snapshot vs an over‑time view of deviation. Static suits point comparisons; over time suits cumulative surplus/deficit patterns.

choices.label: Static
choices.help: Single snapshot comparison.

choices.label: Over time
choices.help: How the deviation evolves across periods.

mag_q0.question: Magnitude of what?
mag_q0.help: Decide the kind of magnitude comparison: basic group sizes, a single quantity, ordered sequences, two independent measures, or prioritising largest contributors.

choices.label: Basic comparisons
choices.help: Compare sizes across groups.

choices.label: One thing
choices.help: Focus on a single quantity.

choices.label: Order is significant
choices.help: Sequence matters, not just size.

choices.label: Two dimensions
choices.help: Two independent magnitude measures (e.g. value and volume).

choices.label: Prioritise biggest contributors
choices.help: Cumulative impact to identify the vital few.

geo_q0.question: Geographic focus?
geo_q0.help: Choose how to show spatial data: points, flows, continuous surfaces, or area‑based units (trust/site). Pick the option that matches your geography and measure type.

choices.label: Basic (points)
choices.help: Locations or counts at points. e.g. sites, incidents, services.

choices.label: Movement
choices.help: Flows or journeys between places.

choices.label: Continuous surface
choices.help: Smoothly varying values over space. e.g. rates across a region.

choices.label: By specific area (trust/site)
choices.help: Area units with boundaries. e.g. trust, site, LSOA.

geo_area.question: Area-based options
geo_area.help: Select how to encode values for area units: choropleth for rates/density, proportional symbols at fixed centroids, or scaled cartograms when size/proximity hides variation.

choices.label: Choropleth
choices.help: Shaded areas by value. Best for rates/densities.

choices.label: Proportional symbol (at fixed positions)
choices.help: Sized symbols at known centroids (e.g. sites).

choices.label: Values hidden due to scale/proximity
choices.help: When small/nearby areas obscure values, distort to reveal them.

comp_q0.question: Composition depth?
comp_q0.help: Pick the part‑to‑whole structure: a single whole, overlaps, or multiple grouping dimensions (2–3).

choices.label: 1 dimension
choices.help: Parts of a single whole.

choices.label: Cross-over of 2–3 areas
choices.help: Overlap between categories.

choices.label: 2 dimensions
choices.help: Two grouping variables.

choices.label: 3 dimensions
choices.help: Three grouping variables or nested parts.

comp_1d.question: 1D composition specifics
comp_1d.help: Choose how to present a single whole broken into parts: proportional ring, simple few parts, nested sub‑parts, or positive/negative building blocks.

choices.label: Donut (part-to-whole)
choices.help: Share/proportion of categories.

choices.label: Only 2–3 components
choices.help: Very few parts — emphasise simplicity.

choices.label: Deeper detail within the dimension
choices.help: Drill into sub-parts within the same whole.

choices.label: Positive and negative components
choices.help: Show how additions and subtractions build to a total.

rank_q0.question: How many ranked components?
rank_q0.help: Choose whether you’re ranking one list or comparing ranks across two lists/time points.

choices.label: One
choices.help: Single ranking list.

choices.label: Two
choices.help: Compare ranks across two lists/time points.

rank_one.question: Any constraints?
rank_one.help: State presentation constraints for a single ranking: add extra detail per item or keep labels short for compact visuals.

choices.label: Extra detail
choices.help: Include additional metrics per item.

choices.label: Short names
choices.help: Use when labels are compact; otherwise tables may be clearer.

dist_q0.question: Distribution scope?
dist_q0.help: Select whether you’re inspecting one group’s distribution or comparing distributions across groups.

choices.label: Single component
choices.help: Distribution of one group.

choices.label: Split into components
choices.help: Compare distributions across groups.

dist_split.question: How many components?
dist_split.help: Pick two groups for side‑by‑side comparison or a few groups for multi‑group summaries.

choices.label: Two
choices.help: Two groups side‑by‑side.

choices.label: A few
choices.help: Several groups to compare.
